I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In November 2001, the World Trade Organization (WTO) launched a new round of 
multilateral trade negotiations known as the Doha Development Agenda (DDA), or Doha Round, 
to revitalize the world economy through the expansion of trade. As trade plays a key role in 
reducing poverty through faster economic growth, international institutions are invited to assist 
developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  in  international  trade.  Capacity  development  is 
particularly essential, to integrate the DMCs into the WTO multilateral trading system, as called 
for in the statements of the Group of Seven (G7), Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) 
leaders’ meetings, and WTO ministerial conferences. 
2.  In  May  2002,  the  WTO  and  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  concluded  a 
memorandum of understanding to cooperate in technical assistance in WTO-related issues in 
the region. At the request of the Government of Japan, made to the President on behalf of the 
APEC economies, ADB’s Economics and Research Department launched three WTO-related 
capacity development programs in 2002,1 2003,2 and 2004.3 The responses to an evaluation 
questionnaire  indicated  that  these  activities  have  achieved  the  expected  outcomes.  Many 
participants  also  requested  a  focus  on  trade  facilitation  in  future  capacity  development 
programs.4   
3.  The proposed capacity development program is supported by technical assistance (TA). 
The fourth of this kind, it is designed to provide technical inputs to customs administrations of 
DMCs that are members of the WTO to help them develop a detailed plan for implementing the 
Agreement on Trade Facilitation. Appendix 1 gives the framework of the TA.5 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  In July 2004, the General Council of the WTO, the highest decision-making body of the 
organization, decided to include trade facilitation in the Doha Round as a new area under the 
so-called “July 2004 Package.” Trade facilitation negotiations in the DDA cover public trade 
procedures for exports and imports, but almost all of these are customs-related and the WTO 
has no clear and detailed rules for trade facilitation at present.  
5.  Trade facilitation is essential for trade expansion. Recent ADB and APEC studies show 
that trade facilitation measures would generate more gains than trade liberalization measures.6 
WTO  members  must  implement  all  the  DDA  agreements  under  the  “single  undertaking” 
commitment, but implementing the lengthy agreement (Appendix 2), with its detailed provisions, 
would be burdensome to DMCs, particularly their customs authorities.

2   
6.  Before  the  start  of  negotiations  for  trade  facilitation,  DMCs  demanded  and  got  a 
commitment from all WTO members that technical assistance and capacity development in both 
trade facilitation negotiations and implementation of the agreement on trade facilitation would be 
provided to them. In fact, the July 2004 Package for Modalities for Negotiations on Trade 
Facilitation states that 
7.  Negotiations shall aim to clarify and improve relevant aspects of Articles V (freedom of 
transit),  VIII  (fees  and  formalities  connected  with  importation  and  exportation),  and  X 
(publication and administration of trade regulation) of the 1994 General Agreement on Tariffs 
and Trade with a view to further expediting the movement, release and clearance of goods…. 
8.  It  is  recognized  that  the  provision  of  technical  assistance  and  support  for  capacity 
building is vital for developing and least-developed countries to enable them to fully participate 
in and benefit from the negotiations. 
9.  Support and assistance should also be provided to help developing and least-developed 
countries implement the commitments resulting from the negotiations…. 
10.  In  order  to  make  technical  assistance  and  capacity  building  more  effective  and 
operational  and  to  ensure  better  coherence,  Members  shall  invite  relevant  international 
organizations…to undertake a collaborative effort in this regard. 
11.  To date, more than 140 proposals on various elements of trade facilitation have been 
submitted. It is expected that, once the DDA freeze is lifted, a first draft agreement on trade 
facilitation will be tabled. It is therefore necessary to provide capacity development to customs 
administrations  of  DMCs  that  are  WTO  members  for  the  smooth  implementation  of  the 
Agreement on Trade Facilitation. Capacity development in the following areas is particularly 
vital: 
(i)  examination of the contents of the agreement and identification of the obligations 
of WTO members under the agreement; 
(ii)  listing of legal, operational, and organizational measures and changes required 
to implement the agreement in the light of the existing framework; and 
(iii)  preparation of a realistic implementation plan.        
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The TA will enable DMCs to develop a plan for implementing the WTO Agreement on 
Trade Facilitation. To this end, the TA will provide the DMCs with a clear understanding of the 
contents  of  the  Agreement  on  Trade  Facilitation,  in  particular  the  obligations  of  customs 
administrations under the agreement, to equip the DMCs and their customs administrations with 
the necessary knowledge and skills.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA’s capacity development program has four components.   
Customs  DG-Commissioner  Meeting  on  Trade  Facilitation,  February  2007,  Asian 
Development Bank Institute (ADBI), Tokyo. This 3-day high-level meeting will focus on policy 
aspects of the Agreement on Trade Facilitation, e.g., the political importance of the agreement

3
in international trade, and the economic benefits from the implementation of the agreement. 
Other key trade facilitation issues, such as partnership with the private sector, use of information 
technology, and regional cooperation, will also be addressed.  At the same time, the proposed 
regional TA will be introduced to maximize its benefits to the DMCs. The World Customs 
Organization (WCO) and the Customs and Tariff Bureau of Japan’s Ministry of Finance will fully 
collaborate with ADB in this activity. Customs directors-general and commissioners from 23 
selected DMCs will be invited to participate.  
14.  Intensive Course on Obligations of Customs Administration under the Agreement 
on Trade Facilitation, June 2007, Thailand Resident Mission, Bangkok, Thailand. This 5-
day training course will address the contents of the agreement and the obligations of WTO 
members under it. It will require detailed technical analysis of the agreement. In addition, the 
obligations of customs administration under the agreement must be identified in a detailed and 
precise manner in preparation for the next step, i.e., comparison of the legal framework with the 
obligations under the agreement.  Customs officials with the rank of director who take charge of 
trade facilitation in 23 selected DMCs will be invited to participate. 
15.  Intensive Course on Possible Measures and Changes Required to Implement the 
Agreement on Trade Facilitation, March 2008, Customs Academy, Malacca, Malaysia. This 
8-day course will examine the differences between the customs-related laws of DMCs and the 
DMCs’ obligations under the agreement. These differences, which will vary between DMCs, 
must be identified before amendments to the customs-related laws, regulations, and directives 
are drafted to implement the agreement. WCO is expected to undertake case studies on the 
differences between the customs-related laws of a couple of DMCs and present the outcome at 
this course. Customs officials with the rank of director who are in charge of trade facilitation in 
23 selected DMCs will participate. 
16.  Intensive  Course  on  the  Implementation  Plan  of  the  Agreement  on  Trade 
Facilitation,  June  2008,  ADBI,  Tokyo,  Japan.    This  5-day  course  will  examine  the 
implementation plans prepared, submitted, and presented by the DMCs. Experts will provide 
technical advice on trade facilitation to enable the implementation plan to be finalized. Customs 
officials with the rank of director who are involved in drafting the implementation plan for the 
Agreement on Trade Facilitation in 23 selected DMCs will attend the course. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $450,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on 
a grant basis from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The details of 
the cost estimates and financing plan are shown in Appendix 3. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  ADB’s Economics Research Department will implement the TA in cooperation with WCO 
and the Government of Japan. Implementation is expected to begin in January 2007 and to end 
in September 2008. A detailed curriculum for the four intensive courses will be developed in 
collaboration with WCO and the Customs Authority of the Government of Japan. WTO, WCO, 
and customs authorities of Australia, Japan, and New Zealand are expected to provide experts 
in trade facilitation.

4   
19.  Twelve resource persons who are experts in trade facilitation will be recruited for 2 
person-months for the high-level meeting and the three intensive courses. They will be hired 
individually by ADB according to its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (April 2006, as 
amended from time to time). The TA will finance travel and per diem, as well as the honoraria of 
resource persons in certain cases (Appendix 4). The customs authorities of Australia, Japan, 
and New Zealand are, however, expected to partly finance the participation of their experts as 
in-kind contributions to the program.   
20.  The  DMC  participants  will  come  from  Bangladesh;  Brunei  Darussalam;  Cambodia; 
People’s Republic of China; Fiji Islands; Hong Kong, China; India; Indonesia; Republic of Korea; 
Kyrgyz  Republic;  Malaysia;  Maldives;  Mongolia;  Myanmar;  Nepal;  Pakistan;  Papua  New 
Guinea;  Philippines;  Singapore;  Solomon  Islands;  Sri  Lanka;  Taipei,China;  and  Thailand.7  
Hong  Kong,  China;  Republic  of  Korea;  Singapore;  and  Taipei,China  will  be  requested  to 
shoulder the cost of their participation in the four activities. 
21.  Information  about  the  four  activities  will  be  published  on  ADB’s  Web  site.  The 
participants will evaluate the activities through a structured questionnaire.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 on a grant basis for 
the Capacity Development of Selected Developing Member Countries on the Implementation of 
the Trade Facilitation Agreement of the World Trade Organization, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board. 
 
 
                                                 
7  Tonga and Viet Nam have been admitted to WTO subject to the necessary domestic ratification procedures. Once 
these procedures are completed, these countries will be included in this regional TA.

Appendix 2  7
 
PROPOSED ELEMENTS OF AN AGREEMENT ON TRADE FACILITATION 
1.  The World Trade Organization Secretariat has compiled its members’ proposals on trade 
facilitation in the following elements: 
(i)   Publication  and  availability  of  information  (publication  of  trade  regulations, 
publication  of  penalty  provisions,  internet  publication,  notification  of  trade 
regulations,  establishment  of  enquiry  points/single  national  focal 
points/information centers, and other measures to enhance the availability of 
information).  
(ii)   Time  period  between  publication  and  implementation  (interval  between 
publication and entry into force).  
(iii)   Consultation and comment on new and amended rules (prior consultation and 
commenting on new and amended rules; and information on policy objectives 
sought).  
(iv)   Advance rulings (provision of advance ruling).  
(v)   Appeal procedures (right of appeal; release of goods in event of appeal).  
(vi)   Other  measures  to  enhance  impartiality  and  nondiscrimination  (uniform 
administration of trade regulations; maintenance and reinforcement of integrity 
and ethical conduct among officials).  
(vii)   Fees  and  charges  connected  with  importation  and  exportation  (general 
disciplines on fees/charges imposed on or in connection with importation and 
exportation;  reduction/ minimization  of  the  number  and  diversity  of  fees and 
charges).  
(viii)   Formalities connected with importation and exportation (disciplines on formalities/ 
procedures  and  data/documentation  requirements  connected  with  importation 
and exportation):  
(a)   nondiscrimination,  
(b)   periodic review of formalities/procedures and requirements,  
(c)   reduction/limitation  of  formalities/procedures  and  data/documentation 
requirements,  
(d)   use of international standards, 
(e)  uniform customs code,  
(f)   acceptance of commercially available information and copies,  
(g)  automation (computerized customs procedure processing system), 
(h)  single window/one-time submission,  
(i)   elimination of preshipment inspection, and 
(j)   phasing out mandatory use of customs brokers.  
(ix)   Consularization (prohibition of consular transaction requirement).  
(x)   Border agency coordination (coordination of activities and requirements of all 
border agencies).  
(xi)   Release and clearance of goods (expedited/simplified release and clearance of 
goods; establishment and publication of average release and clearance time):  
(a)   prearrival clearance,  
(b)   expedited procedures for express shipments,  
(c)   risk management/analysis, authorized traders,

8  Appendix 2 
(d)  postclearance audit,  
(e)   separating release from clearance procedures, and 
(f)   other measures to simplify customs release and clearance.  
(xii)   Tariff classification (objective criteria for tariff classification).  
(xiii)   Matters relating to goods in transit (strengthened nondiscrimination, disciplines 
on  fees  and  charges,  disciplines  on  transit  formalities  and  documentation 
requirements,  improved  cooperation  and  coordination,  operationalization  and 
classification of terms).  
(xiv)   Information exchange mechanism (multilateral mechanism for the exchange and 
handling of information). 
 
Source:  World  Trade  Organization.  2006.  WTO  Negotiations  on  Trade  Facilitation  Compilation  of  Members’

10  Appendix 4 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
(RESOURCE PERSONS) 
 
 
1.  The technical assistance will provide services from resource persons. The basic task of the 
twelve  high-caliber  resource  persons1 will  be  to  make  presentations  at  the  Customs  DG-
Commissioner Meeting and the three intensive courses. They will be asked to prepare and submit 
their presentation materials on a specified date, lead the discussions, and channel the dialogue 
among participants on the following topics.  
 
 
A.  Customs-DG Commissioner Meeting on Trade Facilitation 
2.  The resource persons will have in-depth understanding of: 
(i)  political and economic importance of trade facilitation within and outside the Doha 
Development Agenda negotiations, and 
(ii)  trade facilitation initiative being undertaken by customs administrations.  
 
B.  Intensive Course on Obligations of Customs Administration under the Agreement on 
Trade Facilitation  
3.  The resource person will have comprehensive knowledge of: 
(i)  in-depth analysis of the Agreement on Trade Facilitation, and 
(ii)  obligations of customs administrations under the Agreement on Trade Facilitation.   
 
C.  Intensive Course on Possible Measures and Changes Required to Implement the 
Agreement on Trade Facilitation 
4.  The  resource  persons  will  be  able  to  discuss  thoroughly  the  possible  measures  and 
changes required to implement the Agreement on Trade Facilitation. They should also present two 
case studies involving developing member countries. 
 
D.  Intensive Course on the Implementation Plan of the Agreement on Trade Facilitation 
 
5.  The resource persons will have expertise in: 
 
(i)  legal, operational, organizational, and training aspects of the implementation of the 
Agreement on Trade Facilitation. 
 
6.  The resource persons will work in close collaboration with the Asian Development Bank 
staff in preparing specific materials for their presentations.   
 
                                                 
1  About three resource persons for each activity.
